Find an expression for \(f(x)\) in the form \(f(x)=a\cdot \sin(x)\) or \(f(x)=a\cdot \cos(x)\), where \(a\in \mathbb{Z}\).

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

We first determine the value of \(a\), which defines the amplitude, or the vertical stretch of the graph. The range of the sine and cosine graphs is \([-1,1]\). Since the maximum of this graph is {@aa@} and the minimum {@-aa@}, the value of \(a\) has to be {@aa@} as this is the stretch factor.

Now we determine whether the function is a sine or cosine function. We can find this by looking at the \(y-\)intercept and recalling that the graph of the function \(f(x)={@aa*sin(x)@}\) goes through the origin, i.e. \((0,0)\), since the sine graph goes through the origin. Similarly, the graph of the function \(f(x)={@aa*cos(x)@}\) goes through \((0,{@aa@})\) since the cosine graph passes through the point \((0,1)\). In this case, the graph passes through \((0,{@aa@})\) and we conclude that the correct expression for \(f(x)\) is \(f(x)={@ta1@}\).
